hints_html:
The derivative of \(1+x^3\) is almost \(x^2\).

Use a change of variable.

Use the change of variable \(u = 1+x^3\).
hints_raw:
The derivative of <math>1+x^3</math> is almost <math>x^2</math>.
Use a change of variable.
Use the change of variable <math>u = 1+x^3</math>.
question: 1 (a)
sols_html:
We notice that the term \(x^2\) is almost the derivative of what is inside of the square root (up to a constant term) and so we will use a change of variable.

Let \(u = x^3+1\). Then we have:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{du}{dx} = 3x^2\end{aligned}\]

and hence

\[\begin{aligned} du = 3x^2 \, dx\end{aligned}\]

or to match what we have in our integral:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{3} \, du = x^2 \, dx\end{aligned}\]

Since this is a definite integral, we also need to change the bounds of integration. If \(x=-1\) then \(u=0\) and if \(x=0\) then \(u=1\). This allows us to write:

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{-1}^0 x^2 \sqrt{1+x^3} \,dx = \int_0^1 \frac{1}{3} \sqrt{u} \,du\end{aligned}\]

Which is an easy integral to compute:

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^1 \frac{1}{3} \sqrt{u} \,du &= \frac{1}{3} \int_0^1 u^{1/2} \,du = \frac{1}{3} \left[ \frac{2}{3} u^{3/2} \right]_0^1 \\ &= \frac{1}{3} \left( \frac{2}{3} \cdot 1^{3/2} - \frac{2}{3} \cdot 0^{3/2} \right) = \frac{2}{9}.\end{aligned}\]

For such an integral, you do not have to do the change of variable if you can directly figure out the correct antiderivative. Since you have the \(x^2\) term outside of the square root, you expect the antiderivative to be something like:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle (1+x^3)^{3/2}\end{aligned}\]

Taking the derivative of this, you will see how to modify the constants to make it work:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dx} \left[ (1+x^3)^{3/2} \right] = \frac{3}{2} (1+x^3)^{1/2} \, 3x^2 = \frac{9}{2} \, x^2 \sqrt{1+x^3}\end{aligned}\]

And so we know that an antiderivative of \(x^2 \sqrt{1+x^3}\) will be \(\frac{2}{9} (1+x^3)^{3/2}\). Which allows us to conclude:

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{-1}^0 x^2 \sqrt{1+x^3} dx = \left[ \frac{2}{9} (1+x^3)^{3/2} \right]_{-1}^0 = \frac{2}{9}\end{aligned}\]
